description: Scoring criteria for evaluating LRD (Little Red Dot) paper relevance on a 0-10 scale

scoring_categories.name: Core LRD Focus
scoring_categories.description: How directly the paper studies Little Red Dots as the primary research object

evaluation_criteria.indicator: Primary research focus is LRDs (appears in title, central hypothesis)
LRDs are major component of analysis (multi-object study, large LRD sample)
LRDs mentioned as part of broader context (comparative study, few LRDs in sample)
LRDs only mentioned tangentially or in passing
No mention of LRDs or closely related phenomena

scoring_categories.name: Observational Techniques
scoring_categories.description: Relevance and quality of observational data used to study LRDs

evaluation_criteria.indicator: Direct JWST observations (NIRSpec spectroscopy, NIRCam imaging)
Multi-wavelength data including JWST + X-ray/Radio/ALMA
JWST photometry or non-JWST spectroscopy
Ground-based or archival data (HST, Spitzer)
Purely theoretical or simulation study (no observational data)
No observational connection to LRDs

scoring_categories.name: Physical Properties Investigated
scoring_categories.description: Depth of analysis on key LRD physical properties

evaluation_criteria.indicator: Analyzes 4+ key properties with detailed measurements/constraints
Investigates 2-3 key properties
Discusses 1 key property
Properties mentioned but not analyzed
Major discovery or paradigm-shifting result (first detection, new population)
Significant advancement (resolves debate, new constraints, large sample study)
Moderate contribution (confirms previous findings, incremental progress)
Minor contribution (methodological, observational report)
No clear scientific advance related to LRDs

scoring_categories.name: Methodological Rigor
scoring_categories.description: Quality and robustness of the research methodology

evaluation_criteria.indicator: Large sample (N > 100) with rigorous statistical analysis
Moderate sample (10 < N < 100) with careful analysis
Small sample (N < 10) but detailed case study
Single object or theoretical work
Methodology unclear or not applicable to LRDs

0-3.label: Peripheral / Low Relevance
0-3.description: Paper mentions LRDs tangentially or focuses on unrelated topics. Not suitable for detailed LRD study.

4-6.label: Moderate Relevance
4-6.description: Paper discusses LRDs but not as primary focus, or provides contextual information. Useful for background.

7-8.label: High Relevance
7-8.description: Paper is dedicated to LRD research with significant findings. Core literature for understanding LRDs.

9-10.label: Central / Seminal
9-10.description: Landmark LRD paper with major discoveries or definitive studies. Essential reading.

boost_factors: Resolves key debates in LRD nature (AGN vs starburst)
Measures black hole masses and Eddington ratios
Discovers new LRD population or extreme objects
Published in high-impact journal (Nature, Science, ApJL)
reduce_factors: Only mentions LRDs in literature review
No original LRD data or analysis
Focuses on different galaxy types with brief LRD comparison
Redshift mismatch (studies z < 2 when LRDs are z > 4)
No clear connection to LRD properties or formation

usage_instructions.prompt_template:
You are an expert astrophysics reviewer specializing in high-redshift galaxy evolution and Little Red Dot (LRD) research. Score the provided paper's relevance to LRD research on a scale of 0-10 based on the criteria in lrd_ranking_criteria.json.

For each scoring category:
1. Evaluate the paper against the evaluation criteria
2. Assign a score (0-10) for that category
3. Weight the category score according to its importance
4. Calculate final weighted average

Return ONLY a valid JSON object with this exact structure:
{
  "category_scores": {
    "core_lrd_focus": {"score": 8.5, "reasoning": "..."},
    "observational_techniques": {"score": 9.0, "reasoning": "..."},
    "physical_properties": {"score": 7.0, "reasoning": "..."},
    "scientific_impact": {"score": 8.0, "reasoning": "..."},
    "methodological_rigor": {"score": 7.5, "reasoning": "..."}
  },
  "final_score": 8.2,
  "justification": "2-3 sentence summary of why this paper received this score",
  "key_factors": ["JWST NIRSpec data", "Large sample size", "BH mass measurements", "Resolves AGN vs starburst debate"],
  "notebooklm_recommendation": "High priority for NotebookLM"
}

Be objective, specific, and ground your evaluation in the paper's title and abstract.
special_considerations: Papers published before JWST launch (2022) may have lower observational scores unless predicting/analyzing future observations
Review papers can have high impact scores even with no original data
Case studies of single objects can score highly if they reveal new physics or extreme properties
Theoretical papers should be evaluated on their predictive power and connection to observable LRD properties
